titleInfo.title: Silver Dollar Saloon and W. F. N. Ease barbershop

mods.abstract: View from the street of the Silver Dollar Saloon in V.E. Schwab Building on Broadway and Second Avenue. The "Lodging & Lunch" sign on one of the windows has lost several letters. Other signs on the building advertise the times for lunch, prices for lunch, and Gerst Beer. The windows next to the entrance to the Saloon display a variety of bottles. The adjacent W.F.N. Ease barbershop has its prices for a shave and haircut painted on their storefront windows. A sign advertising the Eelbeck Printing Co. is above the barbershop. One person is visible in one of the open windows above the barbershop. Two people are standing on the sidewalk. The streets at the intersection are brick.

The Silver Dollar Saloon, located at 100 Market Street (Second Avenue), is a three-story Romanesque brick building designed by architect Julius G. Zwicker and completed in 1893. In 1889, V. E. Schwab purchased the property at Broad and Market Street. The building has terra cotta details, including a wreath and shells on the fa√ßade. A turret is above the main entrance to the building. Other architectural details include a large cornice with a terracotta frieze, stringcourse molding, and large encased arched windows on the second floor. The building's name came from the floors made of silver dollars. V. E. Schwab was associated with George A. Dickel & Co., as his brother-in-law was George A. Dickel, and the saloon served their whiskey. The saloon attracted riverboat crews who worked nearby, with it offering drinks, lunch, and lodging. During prohibition, the saloon transformed into a soft drink emporium and restaurant.
